{"step_by_step_thinking": "Acetone breath is not a feature of liver disease, sinusitis, or renal disease. It is, however, a feature of diabetes mellitus. This is because when the body doesn't have enough insulin to use glucose for energy, it starts to break down fat for fuel. This process produces a buildup of acids in the bloodstream called ketones, and one type of ketone is acetone. If the ketones build up, the body will try to get rid of them through urine and breath, which can cause the breath to smell like acetone.", "answer_choice": "D"}
